data.body: Fixes to allow Linux to build

data.title: Fixes a runtime JIT that was occurring on iOS
data.body:
The AOT compiler was not able to resolve the List<AddJournalEntry<T>>
constructor, so AddJournalEntry was moved outside
SortingFilteringCollection, and the generic parameter was removed.  This
is not ideal, but performance shouldn't suffer too much, since we happen
to know that any boxing that would have occurred to IUpdateable or
IDrawable has already occurred before they are stored as Object.

data.title: XNA compatibility improvements and Windows compiles again
data.body:
Got a few miscellaneous XNA compatibility improvements and fixes to make the Windows project build again.

I have no clue if it actually runs at all... still working on that part.

Also i have no clue if inadvertently broke the other platforms... but i was very careful.

data.title: Mac blocking fixes
data.body:
### MacGamePlatform
- Now uses NSWindowDelegate implementations for observing MainWindow.
  This seems to be more reliable that subscribing to the .Net events
  exposed by NSWindow.
- Now tracks current RunState (NotStarted, Running, Exiting, Exited)
- Exposes several run-state-derived properties (IsRunning, IsExiting,
  HasExited)
### MacGamePlatform+Synchronous
- Moved all the use-at-your-own-peril Synchronous code into a separate
  file (partial class).
### GameWindow
- Now checks for MacGamePlatform.IsRunning before trying to invoke
  Game.DoUpdate or Game.DoDraw (to avoid Disposed exceptions).

data.title: Changes to ensure things are draw correctly...
data.body: ... In both Landscape and Portrait using ES 1.1 and ES 2.0 code-paths.

data.title: fixed an issue with the Networking causing a Crash on Mac & linux.
data.body:
fixed an issue with the Networking causing a Crash on Mac & linux.
Fixed a issue with the SetData under opengl es 2.0 profile

data.title: Mostly BasicEffect and DrawUserIndexedPrimitive fixes
data.body:
Some fixes to DrawUserIndexedPrimitive.
Basic Support for textureAddressModes (Wrap /Clamp)
Improvements to Color class to match XNA behavior better. (Clamp constructor input values)
Improved PerformanceCounter class. Uses separate PERF_COUNTER define, since you would likely want to run it with optimizations on, not just in DEBUG mode.

I'm pretty new to this GitHub thing, it occurs to me that I maybe should have branched my code of development instead?

data.title: Strict game disposal
data.body:
Game now mimics what the XNA Game object does after it is Disposed.
The effects of this are not evident with the XNA framework itself, since
Game.Run is blocking.  But for iOS and MacOS, the strict disposal checks
make it much easier to debug accidental disposal of the Game object
while it is still in use.

See the associated changes in [MonoGame Sample Pull Request 8](https://github.com/CartBlanche/MonoGame-Samples/pull/8).

data.title: Mac blocking run
data.body:
Makes the BlockingRun test project work correctly.  See [MonoGame Samples Pull Request 7](https://github.com/CartBlanche/MonoGame-Samples/pull/7).
### MacGamePlatform
- Implements RunLoop via a custom NSApplicationDelegate and
  NSWindowDelegate and a manual call to NSApplication.Run.  This is
  unholy magic, but it works well enough for test purposes.
  Asynchronous mode (the default) should be preferred for production.
- Changes the (in my opinion) confusingly-named IsCanShouldUpdate flag
  to SuspendUpdatingAndDrawing(), ResumeUpdatingAndDrawing() and
  AreUpdateAndDrawingSuspended.  Additionally, this eliminates the
  possibility that any kind of reentrancy will cause problems in the
  future.
- Adds 'Disposal' for _mainWindow and _gameWindow.  They actually act a
  little strange because of an interaction with NSAutoreleasePool, so
  further study may be required to ensure they are being properly
  cleaned up.
### GamePlatform
- Formatting and whitespace changes only.

data.title: Scissoring need to allow multiple calls between Begin/End blocks
data.body: Currently Scissoring is only called once , during the End() call. Apparently XNA allows multiple scissor calls between Begin/End blocks.

data.body: This still does not take into account the setting of RunningSlowly

data.title: Implicit ordering fix
data.body: The ordering of IUpdateables and IDrawables is now stable with respect to the order that components are added to the game.  This should fix the issue that @bkane reported.  The test code that verifies the fix is in [MonoGame Samples Pull Request 6](https://github.com/CartBlanche/MonoGame-Samples/pull/6).

data.title: Reduce allocations
data.body:
Inspecting the generated MSIL with ildasm revealed several places where
intermediate objects were being created needlessly each frame.  Lambdas
that require hoisting are the primary offender, but even lambdas that
require no hoisting incur an allocation to convert them to the
appropriate delegate type.  As much of this as possible has been
removed.

data.title: Reduces object allocation in core Game loop, fixes iOS orientation bug from GamePlatform
data.body:
My attempt to avoid the creation of intermediate IEnumerable<T> instances was short-sighted, as it resulted in an equal number of intermediate hoist-local-vars instances.  These changes eliminate all (or nearly so) intermediate allocation in the core Game loop by avoiding hoisting and avoiding delegate creation where possible.

Also included is a minor fix to the iOS view controller that disables auto-rotate, since rotation is already handled by iOSGamePlatform and SpriteBatch.

data.title: Windows Improvements
data.body:
A few fixes to the windows side of MonoGame to help make it more compatible with Microsoft XNA.

Our immediate goal is to get MonoGame compiling against our WP7 game ARMED! (http://www.armedgame.com/) so that we can look to port to iOS and Windows 8 Metro.

data.title: Implementation of iOS VideoPlayer class with the XNA VideoPlayer contract
data.body:
Note that in order to see these changes work, you'll need to also pull the changes made in [MonoGame-Samples Pull Request 4](https://github.com/CartBlanche/MonoGame-Samples/pull/4).  And in order for the samples to look right, the iOS rotation fix in [MonoGame Pull Request 203](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/203) is required.
### Video
- Now marked 'sealed' as in XNA.
- No longer implements IDisposable, since there is nothing left to Dispose of.
- Added pretty-formatted license.
### VideoPlayer
- Entirely reimplemented to conform to the XNA contract.  i.e., consumers must now use GetTexture and draw the texture themselves.
### VideoSoundTrackType
- Implemented and documented.
### iOSGamePlatform
- Eliminated IsPlayingVideo workaround that VideoPlayer needed.
- Eliminated public ViewController property that VideoPlayer needed.
### iOSGameView
- Unused file, deleted.

data.title: Changes to allow iOS to render again.
data.body:
Small change in Game.cs to make Platform_Activate/Deactivated internal, so it could be called from iOSGamePlatform.cs.

Changes in iOSGamePlatform.cs to stop the calls to View.Stop and Resume, as it was destroying the _viewController. 

Moved using Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content; in GraphicsDevice.cs so that is compiles under iOS too.

data.title: Implemented SetData for Texture2D on Android
data.body:
Implemented SetData for Texture2D on Android

Added some simple code to use the current logged in user as the MonoGame user for windows when using the networking.

Did the same for Android but it uses the first account in the account list. This is so the user does not have to type in a name for now until we can get the GamerServies stuff done.

data.title: Reduces object allocation in core Game loop, fixes iOS orientation bug from GamePlatform
data.body:
My attempt to avoid the creation of intermediate IEnumerable<T> instances was short-sighted, as it resulted in an equal number of intermediate hoist-local-vars instances.  These changes eliminate all (or nearly so) intermediate allocation in the core Game loop by avoiding hoisting and avoiding delegate creation where possible.

Also included is a minor fix to the iOS view controller that disables auto-rotate, since rotation is already handled by iOSGamePlatform and SpriteBatch.
